Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2013 09:42AM fd1 wrote: I didn't go through anything like this but if they see a spot why can't they biopsy it?  Maybe you should go for a second opinion just to clarify your options?  One thing I've learned through this whole process is the pushier you are, the better.  Best of luck.  :)
Posts.Title: So Frustrated. Nipple discharge without definitive answers AprilAnnie AprilAnnie

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2013 10:09AM fd1 wrote: Hi Colt45 - I think it was you that was asking questions about recurrence in a previous thread?  Anyways, for sure recurrence rates are highest in the first three years and the further you get from the diganosis the lower the risk.  Most studies state if they are measuring time since diagnosis or treatment.  For example, on cancer.org the survival rates are for overall survival (not recurrence) from diagnosis.  Note that I believe these rates include people who have a recurrence and die within the five-years after diagnosis.  By this I mean, I don't believe you are re-classified as Stage IV if you were originally diagnosed at Stage II and then had a recurrence and died.  If you were, the survival rates for Stage I through III would be the same as the general population. There is one interesting article which shows that the residual risk of recurrence five years after completing adjuvant treatment.  http://jnci.oxfordjournals.org/content/100/16/1179.full It shows that grade 1 tumors tend to recur later than grade 3 tumors, something which has been confirmed by other studies.  Tumors that also tend to recur later are hormone positive and HER2-.  Most medical oncs will consider you cured after 10 years, although there is always a residual risk.  My great aunt had breast cancer in her early 50s and died in her late 80s of brain cancer.  I always wondered if it was a late recurrence of her breast cancer.  Likely not, but who knows! I've come to terms with my risk of recurrence.  Anybody could be diagnosed with a stage IV cancer (or hit by a bus, or die in a plane crash) tomorrow.  Sure, my chances of dying of breast cancer are on average higher than somebody else, but I've done all I can do to minimize that risk.  Now it's about enjoying and not worrying about the things that may or may not happen tomorrow that are out of my control.  Before I came to this conclusion, I read almost every study about prognosis and survival on Google, so it took a while.   I hope that you can come to the same conclusion!
Posts.Title: Recurrence Risk Decreases Over Time? Colt45 SpecialK

Posts.Content: fd1 wrote: I am undergoing 25 radiation treatments for Stage IIB breast cancer.  I had a mastectomy and was in the gray zone for radiation.  After my RO brought up two 20-year studies that show a survival benefit, especially in the long term, for women with similar diagnoses and considering my young age (32), I decided to go ahead with the treatments.  My margins were negative and my tumor was relatively small (2.1 cm).  However, I have just learned that I will be receiving 4 boosts after the 25 treatments.  Is this normal?  Everything that I've read online about post-mastectomy radiation seems to indicate that a boost to the scar would only be considered if the margins were positive.  To be honest though, I have yet to find a clear reference online for standard radiation as there are for chemotherapy.  My treatment centre is supposed to be one of the best in Canada for radiation so I do have some faith in what they are doing but don't want to expose myself to unnecessary treatment.  Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Boost after mastectomy? fd1 windchimes58

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2017 07:15AM - edited Jan 19, 2017 07:17AM by fd1 Hi FaithHope - please don't worry! They shouldn't make these tools available because they are so hard to understand. The 42% is before having any treatment. If you look at the menu for the BC tools you will see one called therapy. If you put your info in there and then the treatments you received, you will see the actual 15 year death rate (which is 15% if I assume that you received standard treatment of 4 x AC, 4 x Taxol dose dense plus tamoxifen)

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2013 05:19AM fd1 wrote: So good to know what everybody is going (or went) through!  My skin seems to have settled down a bit over the weekend, but goodness was I tired.  On Saturday, I slept about 8 hours and had a busy day.  Around 4 p.m. I had a splitting headache and all I wanted to do was nap, but I had to keep going until way after dinner.  That night I slept like a rock for 9.5 hours and I napped for an hour during the day.  I'm feeling better today.  I'm not sure if it was the radiation or some sort of flu bug I was fighting.  My nose was running like crazy all day, so it could be the latter.

Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2013 12:12AM fd1 wrote: Selena, did you have a mastectomy or lumpectomy?  It's so weird, I thought my skin would get tighter around my expander but it seems like it is still stretching.  I'm worried about damaging it if it is fragile or thin or something.  I did read a blog online about an atheltic girl that passed out in a spinning class after suffering a collapsed lung as a side effect of radiation.  I've heard such problems are rare but do occur so definitely see with your doctor what can be done. I'm currently on R # 18 and the skin is still just pink.  There are three smallish spots that are darker.  I had recurring tinea versicolor before all of this so I am wondering if these are that.  I haven't seen the doctor since I started since he's been on vacation and the technicians just told me to keep on with the cream.

Posts.Content: May 24, 2014 03:34AM fd1 wrote: Hi Dancingdiva,   Oh, if only we had as many doctors as we do orange cones!  I was also treated at JGH.  I was 31 when I was diagnosed in January 2012.  I had found the lump myself in August 2011 but because of my age and risk factors, I waited until December for an ultrasound at the hospital.  After waiting a month and half for a surgery date and another couple of weeks for the results, I released that the only way you get through this shoddy Quebec public system is by being polite and pushy.  My husband or I called doctors, their assistants, showed up as if it was a walk-in clinic, monitored ALL my test result, etc.  I did a lot of research online and basically checked everything that my doctor did.  Studies have shown that the pushiest patients have the best survival rates so have no shame.    If you need any specific advice I'd be happy to try to help - you can PM me any time.

Posts.Content: Nov 2, 2015 07:02AM fd1 wrote: Don't feel badly - you are sometimes your only advocate and always your best. Unfortunately, sometimes you don't catch more bees with honey and this was one of those situations.
Posts.Title: I went off, then I felt terrible! etnasgrl Professor50

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2015 01:35PM fd1 wrote: Hi Keepstrong! Sorry that you are here. :( I was hell bent on doing the cold caps too but I'm not sure I'm happy I did. They didn't work for me. In fact, if you are doing AC and Taxol there is very little chance of them working. Not to mention the fact that they are extremely expensive and an additional stress on treatment days! They do work quite well with other chemo protocols - you can see which on their website. My suggestion to you is to invest the money that you would have spent on the caps in some very good wigs. I also completely relate to your feelings of putting your loved ones through this. I felt like that initially too as I have always been an achiever and a good kid, mainly as a reaction to my brother being severely handicapped. I felt it thoroughly unfair that I should be causing more stress to my parents. I realized though that it wasn't my fault and that it was completely necessary for me to be selfish at that time of my life. I hope that you are able to come to that conclusion too. Best wishes.
Posts.Title: 27 & Struggling :( Keepstrong88 nem126

Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2015 06:59AM fd1 wrote: I was 30 when when I was diagnosed. It's going to be four years in January! :) I do agree that seeing somebody helps. I saw a traditional Chinese doctor in our area who helped me deal with everything through meditation and visualization. As for the cold caps, the website shows a 36% success rate with ACT - 4/11 had "adequate" hair protection. I met two other women who did it who were on other chemo drugs and had asked to be put on those because of the better chance of keeping their hair with caps. One had hair that thinned considerably and receded but was intact after treatment. She wore head bands to cover the receded part as it grew back. The other had to wear a demi-wig because she lost most of the hair on the top of her head. Once you find out what regimen you will be having, I suggest seeking out others on the cold cap thread that had success with that regimen and ask them exactly how they define that success. Also, check out the success threads. You will see women who have survived for 5, 10, 15, even 25 years and that includes women with TN. There is hope.
Posts.Title: 27 & Struggling :( Keepstrong88 nem126

Posts.Title: Alcohol & Breast Cancer Recurrence Association Qualified... SelenaWolf taffy_needhelp1234

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2013 06:57AM - edited Jan 31, 2013 06:57AM by fd1 What you wrote about stress, Beesie, is exactly my thought (or justification lol).  But I really believe that the risk comes from the sugar levels in alcohol.  Many studies show that insulin levels may have an impact on recurrence, especially for those who are obese.  The fact that the above study found the negative impact in obese, postmenopausal women, who would be more likely to have blood sugar issues, is very interesting.  So for now, I minimize other dietary sources of sugars/carbs and enjoy un bon verre!

Posts.Content: Aug 28, 2014 10:02AM fd1 wrote: Hi KGB - I did some research on this as this was exactly the treatment that I had at around the same age as your wife (31).  I don't have any links but I read that this combination of drugs is one of the least likely to leave you infertile.  The chances of it putting you in permanent menopause at your wife's age are quite low.  My fertility clinic suggested that I also receive Zoladex or Lupron shots during chemo to protect the ovaries although at that time there were no thorough studies to support it.  These drugs put you into temporary menopause by shutting down the ovaries and there was speculation that this would protect them from the chemo drugs.  I am not sure if any research has proved or disproved this treatment to date but you could speak to your fertility doctor or your oncologist. I stopped my Lupron shots after chemo.  It took a year for my period to return after that.  My doctor then prescribed me Zoladex as an additional adjuvant therapy with Tamoxifen.  I'll stop taking both in a year or so to try for babies!  :) Best of luck - the fertility felt like adding insult to injury and is very difficult for both the patient and her husband!  I can totally relate.
Posts.Title: ACT Therapy and reproduction KGB1985 KGB1985

Posts.Content: May 6, 2013 06:36AM fd1 wrote: It's usually less than 30 ccs of drainage for 48 hours before a drain can be removed.  You look at each drain independently, so don't worry!  I think it was about two weeks before I had both out, but it really depends on the person.  Also, the first time I had a drain removed it was incredibly painful but the other two I didn't feel at all.  Hopefully, it will be the same for you.  :)
Posts.Title: JP Drains - How Long?? turquoiseblue2 turquoiseblue2

Posts.Content: May 15, 2013 09:44AM fd1 wrote: Hi Rachel!  There's more than a good chance that your symptoms are caused by something benign, but I completely undertsand how you are feeling.  I was 30 when diagnosed and was not expecting it at all.  I got an ultrasound first on the lump.  Based on that, they immediately sent me for a mammogram and from there booked an appointment for a biopsy the next day.  They sometimes can do the biopsy on the same day.  It can take anywhere from a few days to a few weeks to get the results from that based on where you are.  Hopefully, you won't even get to that point, but if you do, as jacksnana said, most biopsies come back benign.
Posts.Title: 23yrs old being sent for Triple check appointment. Rachel231 fd1

Posts.Content: May 21, 2013 02:33PM fd1 wrote: Hi Adowney76 - I was diagnosed just before my 31st birthday in January 2012.  It is an asbolutely awful thing to go through at our young age.  The previous poster is right, you won't necessarily need chemo.  The is given to women who have a higher risk of having microscopic disease elsewhere in their body.  It helps prevent the cancer from recurring down the road.  There are so many factors that go into that decision if the lymph nodes are negative that you will not know until you have had your sentinel node biopsy and met with your oncologist. If you are worried about hair loss, I personally know two girls around our age that used the Penguin Cold Caps and kept most of their hair.  There are several women on here who have had success with that too.  It does not work consistently for every chemo regime but it is an option. The other thing that is very important is to look into preserving your fertility.  I haven't had kids yet and I was able to freeze some embryos.  There are many options to help ensure that you will be able to start a family later on in your life.  It takes a while so it's best to get moving on it.  You can always cancel the procedures if you don't end up needing chemo. Best of luck. xoxo

Posts.Content: May 23, 2013 02:42PM fd1 wrote: I also highly recommend the surgery threads.  There is usually one for each month.  You will have a couple days where moving is really not possible.  I tried to sleep in my bed my first night at home and had a panic attack because I couldn't sit up on my own.  I had to wake up my fiance to move me.  I set up a bed on the couch for the next night, but a reclining chair would be ideal.  I'd recommend having a friend or family member plan to stay with you for a few days. Also, get as many loose fitting, zip-up sweatshirts as you can.  You will have drains so if you want to hide them to go out in public, you need to go with the baggy look.

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2013 04:44AM fd1 wrote: Telling people was by the hardest part of all of this in my opinion.  It made me realise that I put this unnecessary pressure on myself to be perfect, to never be the one who needs help or has a problem.  I now have no issue saying no or asking for what I need from those who care about me. I told my parents as soon as I had the official diagnosis and that was the hardest thing I have ever had to do.  I then ignored my friends until after my pathology came back from my surgery, almost a month and a half.  I just didn't have the strength to deal with it right away and before I knew exactly where I stood.  At work, I only told my boss and two of the employees I am closest with.  When I missed work, I told those effected that I was dealing with some personal issues at the moment.  :)
Posts.Title: how many people will I tell about the cancer? kpr msphil

Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2013 02:50AM fd1 wrote: I am at a large, well-renowned teaching hospital in Canada and they do not do MRIs for breast cancer.  When I asked my BS why, he said that they are hyper-sensitive.  There are so many false positives that they cause undue stress to the patient and do not actually determine anything.  As long as you are mentally prepared for that possibility of a false positive and the waiting period between that and the biopsy, I think you are on a good track.
Posts.Title: Advice.... soclueless1 fd1

Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2013 01:54AM fd1 wrote: All I can say is here is a big hug because I feel your pain.  I had a mix-up where the radiation department called me after my surgery to schedule the mapping.  I said I hadn't received the results of my pathology yet and they said that they had and the margins were negative.  I was esctatic for the next hour, called friends and family to relay the good news.  Then my surgeon called to book an appointment on the Monday.  When I asked if I really needed to come in as I already knew the good news, he had to break it to me.  The margins were positive and I needed a mastectomy.  I felt beyond depressed, angry... it felt like a cruel joke.  But everything happens for a reason.  I see it as a push from the universe to do the right thing.  By the way, my mastectomy pathology came back with no residual disease.  :)
Posts.Title: New path report is scaring me! I need some reassurance BeHereNow BeHereNow

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2017 03:28PM fd1 wrote: Hi Jaynina - as Lekker said, it just means that the cancer was starting to grow out of the node. I had a very similar diagnosis - 2.1 cm, 2 nodes positive, largest 5mm with extranodal extension, er+ 100%, pr+ 90% and HER2-, grade 3. I just passed my five year mark since diagnosis, breast cancer free!
Posts.Title: What does 'Extranodal extension present' mean? Jaynina Jaynina

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2013 09:35AM fd1 wrote: I am on the baby Aspirin train too.  There are a lot of studies that hint at a benefit for prostate cancer, breast cancer, and colorectal cancer.  I do believe it has something to do with the anti-inflammatory effect, but is not completely caused by this because other NSAIDs don't have the same effect.  When you really think of it though, all the things that seem correlated with recurrence risk are related to inflammation - obseity, exercise, diet, blood sugar, stress, sleep, etc.  It is so sad that in the last 30 years all we have done with all that money is improve on current treatments.  They need to start exploring other avenues.  We've knocked on the current doors for too long!
Posts.Title: A clue about why aspirin is helpful to cancer patients? TectonicShift fd1

Posts.Content: May 1, 2013 04:18PM - edited May 1, 2013 04:18PM by fd1 http://jco.ascopubs.org/content/28/9/1467.abstract You can see that the hazard ratio for 2-5 times a week, adjusted, is 0.4, while for 6-7 times it is 0.57 and for once it is 0.91.  There is definitely still a benefit for other frequencies, it is just best in the middle.  They also don't know what dosage the women were taking.  It's just preumed to be low dose.
Posts.Title: A clue about why aspirin is helpful to cancer patients? TectonicShift fd1

Posts.Content: May 14, 2013 10:07AM fd1 wrote: The onc appointments are terrible for me too.  All the memories come rushing back.  I always leave flushed and exhausted.  I ended up giving the path reports to my husband to lock away from me.  I'm done with treatments.  What's in those reports doesn't matter any more and reading them was only putting me right back at the beginning of the journey.  Once was enough...
Posts.Title: Almost 3 years out, still so scared I won't see kids grow up Outfield kelly279

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2013 11:09AM - edited Mar 7, 2013 11:12AM by fd1 I eat organic Greek yogurt.  It is a super food, low in calories, but high in protein and other nutrients.  Make sure to read the label, as not all are equal.  My ND said that organic dairy, preferably in its full fat form, is best.  Low fat items have been processed more and therefore may be missing key items that help you digest the good stuff.   I'm not sure how they label stuff in the States, but here it often says "hormone free" on packages where there may be a concern about what the animals were given.  I believe, although I am not 100% sure, that if it is certified organic then the animals have not been given hormones.  I'm always a bit wary though, as I have also read "pesticide free feed" on an organic label.  Does this mean that only the feed was organic?  I'm sure the USDA rules are somewhere on the Internet.

Posts.Title: well THANK HEAVEN-made it to seven! sugarplum sciencegal

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2013 09:40AM fd1 wrote: indenial, I was young when diagnosed also (31) and it seems we felt very similarly.  The anxiety got especially bad when I found out my sentinel node biopsy came back positive.  I looked at survival statistics and got scared and then I realized that the situation was what I made of it.  You will get to a place where you feel ready to conquer, but you will almost certainly have days where you feel hopeless mixed in.  It's definitely a rollercoaster.  My traditional Chinese doctor gave me a mantra which really helped out - I am happy, healthy, strong and fit in body, mind and spirit.  You say it throughout the day, especially when you feel scared or unsure, and eventually you just start to believe it.  You can make up your own or you can find another online I am sure.  Get one and go with it! xoxo
Posts.Title: Please tell me I will survive this. indenial sutherndiva

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2013 04:31PM fd1 wrote: There are so many variables that effect how fast you will recover.  Are you planning a reconstruction?  If yes, this lengthens the recovery time.  I had a single mastectomy with immediate reconstruction (tissue expanders) and I had an implant placed on the healthy side at the same time.  Note that I had my nodes removed prior to this so my recovery was likely faster than most: Day 4 - able to sleep flat in bed and get up on my own Day 7 - able to move relatively freely and do my daily activities Day 14 - both my drains were removed Most younger women I have spoken to that had this surgery were up and about after about a week, albeit slowly.  I hope that you have a speedy recovery!
Posts.Title: Need help Seebha fd1
